titleStmt.title: The Shakespeare Club of Port Gamble, Washington

publicationStmt.p: This edition covers the daybook's entries from December 14 1896 to January 11 1987. Residents of Port Gamble, Washington may be interested in reading this edition, particularly the descendants of the Gove family. Upon doing research, our group realized that the Gove family may have been an important family in the town that worked in tugboat service, which was essential in Kitsap County. There is even a historical house/landmark in town called the Gove House. We imagine that the residents of Port Gamble and descendants of the Gove family would be interested in this edition as it gives a glimpse into what life and leisure was like in the late 1800s.

sourceDesc.p:
The manuscript are meeting minutes contained within a “Day Book” ruled planner of 150 pages. The minutes are handwritten and contain descriptive paragraphs interspersed with cast lists for their reading assignments. Included are two loose-leaf pages of handwritten letters to the club president. Special Collections Manuscripts and Archives, University of Washington Libraries; Shakespeare Club Records Mrs. Ames December 14, 1896 to January 11, 1987
Seattle Special Collections Manuscripts and Archives, University og Washington Libraries 23949118

div.p: Port Gamble, Washington is a windswept town along the Puget sound, and in 1896 its quaint Victorian homes were chiefly occupied by the bourgeois families drawn to Kitsap county for its burgeoning industries. Herein, the records of the Port Gamble Shakespeare club illuminate the lives of some of its prominent female residents; beyond the paper trails left by their husband’s occupations. Consider the Gove family, whose home is now a historic landmark. Its patriarch, William Gove, was a tugboat captain employed by the Puget Mill Company and had moved to Port Gamble with his wife Laura from Maine. Their four daughters were participants in the Shakespeare club, cropping up frequently in cast lists and in correspondence with the club president.

This digital edition of the Port Gamble Shakespeare Society aims to tell the story of the women of the Gove family whose stories have been overlooked in the discussions of historical families in Port Gamble. We hope to highlight the lived experiences and shared relationships of these women. By the 1900 census, all but one member of the Gove family had left Port Gamble. But for an eventful few months in 1896 and 1897, there were marriages, lead roles and deaths all indirectly chronicled through the lens of the Shakespeare club. This edition may be especially interesting for residents of Port Gamble and the descendants of the Gove Family as it intentionally celebrates the lives and relationships of the women of Port Gamble’s Shakespeare Club.

These meeting minutes, recorded in club secretary Mrs. Ame’s exceptional handwriting, were transcribed to the best of the publisher’s ability. Spelling will be retained as written, with an understanding that each transcription of cursive represents a kind of best-guess. Errors, given the spontaneous nature of the text, will be retained. In instances of post-script correction, the original and corrected text will be noted.

list.head: Members for 1897.
list.item: 9 Carrie Gove Berg - Married Nov 24 * 1897 at Townsend
Carrie Gove Berg - Died Nov 6th 1898 at Port Gamble

div.p: Monday the fourth day of January the Shakespeare Club met at the home of the President for the purpose of reading "The Merry Wives of Windsor." The Club was called to order by the President at 7.10 - all member present answering with quotations from the above mentioned play -
Mrs Condon was the only member absent at this meeting -
After the roll call the minutes of the meeting of December twenty first were then read and approved -
There was no meeing on December twenty eight it having been postponed by the President.
Mrs Wylde made the motion & it was deemed by Mrs M. Gove that a note of thanks be extended to Mr Ames for his kindness: in [illegible] for the [illegible] was [illegible] -
Mrs Ames then informed the members that Mr. Cramtie had very kindly provided the Club with the [illegible] & candy for the ?tree? for which she han thanked him for in behalf of the Club.
There being no further business to attend to - Mrs [illegible] then read ?the? ?Gove? [illegible] [illegible] ?words? - that had had been given the Club two weeks previous.
After this Miss E. Gove then gave her idea of the forms of the affected works is the II ?chopin? of [illegible]

At 7.40 - the reading of the play, Merry Wives of Windsor was begun & finish at 10.15 at which time the Club adjourned -- to meet the following Monday- the place of meeting being Mrs. Gove's & the play to be Merchant of Venice - which had been cast as follows by Mrs. Robinson
On the Eleventh of January the Shakespeare Club met at Miss Gove's for the purpose of Reading The Merchant of Venice.
The President called the Club to order at 7.15. The roll call was given & all members being present & answering with quotations from the above mentioned play.

After the roll call the minutes of the meeting of Jan. 4th were read & approved- Mrs. Ames there ?from? ?gift? ?are? the [illegible] use of several ?words? that had been discussed at the meeting of the 4th after which they one hour was spent in discussing [illegible!] [illegible] from the ?guidance!? [illegible]—which the President read.

At 8 o'clock- began reading The Merchant of Venice- ?all? reading through two scenes of the third act. [Illegible] there being ?few? [illegible] at which time the adjourned to meet on Monday the 18th, 1897, the place of meeting being Mrs. Wylde's at which ?time? The Merchant of Venice is to be finished and a part of Romeo & Juliet which had been cast by Mrs. Wylde with cast as follows-
On the eighteenth of January, Shakespeare Club met at Mrs Condon's. The place of meeting has been changed by Mrs. Condon--
At ten minutes past seven the President called the Club to order - all members being present, and answering with quotations from Merchant of Venice & Romeo & Juliet.
After the roll call the minutes of January Eleventh were read and approved--
There being no business to attend to- the President gave questions from the Grammar which were discussed for some twenty minutes.

At 7-35- began reading at the III scene of the IV act of Merchant of Venice the remainder of the play being finished at 8.55- at which time fifteen minutes was spent discussing. At 9.05-- began the reading of Romeo & Juliet & finishing the first act it being ten at which time the Club adjourned to meet at Mrs. Wylde's-- January twenty-fifth Romeo & Juliet.
On January twenty-fifth the Shakespeare Club met at Mrs. Wylde's.
At 7.10 - the Club was called to order. The roll call given & all members being present and answering with quotation from Romeo & Juliet.
After the roll call the minutes of the previous meeting were read & approved-- after which some 30 minutes was spent in questions from the Grammar.
At 7.50 -- began the reading of Romeo & Juliet. At the second act & reading through the fourth act.

it then being ten o'clock at which time the Club adjourned to meet February 1st the place of meeting being Mrs. Fitzhenry's. The reading to be the last act of Romeo & Juliet and a part of Much Ado About Nothing, which had been cast as follows by Mrs. Ames
On the 1st of February the Shakespeare Club met at Mrs. Fitzhenry's
At 7.20 the Club was called to order by the President. The roll call given the members present answering with quotations from Much Ado About Nothing
Mrs. Fickett was absent at the meeting.
After the roll call the minutes of the meeting of F January 25th were ommission and approved.
Some ten minutes was then spent with questions from the grammar.
There being no business to attend to the Reading began at 7.35, reading the last act of Romeo & Juliet it being finished at 7.58--

Much Ado About Nothing was then taken up and four acts were read 00 and finished at ten o'clock at which time the Club adjourned to meet February 8th the place of meeting being Mrs. Fickett's and the reading is to be the last act of Much Ado and a portion of Twelfth Night which had been cast by Mrs. Condon with cast as follows
On February 8th the Shakespeare Club met at the home of Mrs. Fickett.
The club was called to order at 7.15. The roll call given and all members present answering with quotations from Twelfth Night.
Miss Gove was absent from this meeting.

Miss Robinson informed the Club that she would be absent from the Club on Feb. 15th & probably Feb. 22nd and Mrs. Wylde made the motion that someone be appointed to fill the place of President during the absence. Mrs. Ames was mentioned, voted on and received a unanimous vote to act in the capacity of President during the few meeting [sic] at which Miss Robinson would be absent.
There being no further business to attend to, Miss RObinson then gave some questions from the Grammar--
Ten minutes were thus satisfied.
At 7.35- began the reading of Much Ado About Nothing beginning at the 5th act and the play was finished.
Twelfth Night was begun - & reading through two acts
At 10- the Club adjourned to meet February 15th the place of meeting being Miss Ame's the play being
As You Like It which had been cast as follows by

list.item: (Dennis/2nd Lord/Lord/ Sir Oliver Martex) Mrs Fitzhenry.

div.p: Carrie told me to-day that mention was made at the Club last evening about my non-attendance, so I decided to address an explanation to you as President.

When the Club first formed for this winter, I told the members that I could not possible attend while Carrie and Emily were both away from home as I had no time for study and did not want to go with my lesson unprepared. I also said I thought that I could begin again at the first of the year.
But I did not know then that Carrie would be married soon. You can see that now she is gone & I am in the same predicament I was before.
I did not think about resigning, for I hoped to be able to attend before very long, and also wished to help the Club in anything they might understake for Xmas, etc.

Now that we have decided to move to Port Townsend in three or four months, I think it may be well for me to hand in my resignation. So will you kindly inform the Club of my desire that they may take the necessary action.
I have enjoyed the work and sociability very much and hope the society will ever be as earnest and enjoyable as when I was in it.
If there is ever anything I can do to help you, please let me know as I will always be interested.
Hoping my explanation is acceptable, and wishing you all sucess, I remain

div.note: Port Gamble, Washington is a windswept town along the Puget sound, and in 1896 its quaint historic homes were chiefly occupied by the bourgeois families drawn to Kitsap county for its burgeoning industries.

Port Townsend is a city in Jefferson County known for its rich history, especially its Victorian architecture from the 19th century. The city is known for its boatbuilders and considered to be a maritime center.

This is a Shakespearean comedy that depicts Sir John Falstaff's attempts to seduce two married women, Mistress Ford and Mistress Page. This leads to a series of comical misunderstandings and the clever wives outwitting the would-be seducer in the bustling town of Windsor.
This is a Shakespearean comedy that follows the story of a merchant named Antonio, his friend Bassanio, the wealthy heiress Portia, and the moneylender Shylock in Venice and Belmont.

This is a tragic play by William Shakespeare that tells the story of two young lovers from feuding families in Verona, whose passionate romance ultimately leads to their untimely deaths and reconciliation between their rival families.
